top_categories.workout_context: Rebecca's Private Idaho’s high desert gravel with sustained climbs and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
At 103 miles, Rebecca's Private Idaho punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Racing Rebecca's Private Idaho isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Rebecca's Private Idaho’s high desert gravel, mountain passes demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Rebecca's Private Idaho rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Rebecca's Private Idaho when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Every session at Rebecca's Private Idaho intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Rebecca's Private Idaho. Make this intensity feel like home.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Rebecca's Private Idaho — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Rebecca's Private Idaho’s 8,500ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Rebecca's Private Idaho — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on high desert gravel with sustained climbs.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Rebecca's Private Idaho’s high desert gravel with sustained climbs delivers on race day.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Rebecca's Private Idaho’s 103 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: Rebecca's Private Idaho with 8,500ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Altitude at 6,000-8,000 feet.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Rebecca's Private Idaho requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on high desert gravel with sustained climbs to build confidence. Expect: high desert gravel, mountain passes, scenic forest roads.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on VO2max, Durability, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 103 miles of high desert gravel with sustained climbs in Ketchum, Idaho.
